reviewText: I'm a sci-fi junkie. There are few one-off movies worth watching more than once and this is one of them. I've loved this movie since seeing it way back when in the theater. That being said, I've seen this move... a lot!This was my second Blu-ray purchase. Given the number of times I've seen this film and my eye for detail in media I have to say this is a vast improvement over any copy of this movie you have seen. The colors are really, sharp, the background pops, and you'll notice things you had never seen before - the whole point of owning ANY movie in HD.If you're a fan of the movie it is a must have!

reviewText: We have seen this movie more times then other movie made.Wife is a Huge Bruce Willis fan, I think he's good in certain things this and the original Die Hard are his 2 best, imho.This Movie However is a real masterpiece and has a little bit something for everyone Action, humor, storyline, nudity, a plethora of sexual undertones, a moral and incredible CGI, cutting edge for its time.Luc Besson is somewhat of a god when it comes to directing and writing I truly appreciate the crazy risk and wild turns spinning around in his head however I don/t always appreciate his genius. (I'm sure its just my inferior mind unable to comprehend what he's trying to lay down) The Fifth Element, The Professional & La Femme Nikita (1990) are Stellar films.We have been using this movie to judge all of our latest TV screen purchases  for many years and we were completely horrified by how cheesy the graphics  looked on a 65" 240hz LED screen.However the Remastered Blu-Ray is a Phenomenal accomplishment. I was thrilled to find the Remastered version on Amazon and ordered the same afternoon we hooked up new TV.

reviewText: This film is a visual feast to watch - with the sound off. The plot is so dumb, the script-writer's brain was missing in action here, I think. Characters are cardboard stereotypes. Why should the species who have come to save us from "ultimate evil" arrive in a fragile spaceship that can be destroyed by a few bozos in fighter ships? Why do we have to listen to the Hero's stupid mother complaining - at all? The "Ruby Rhod" character (Chris Tucker) is beyond irritating. Fine actors like Ian Holm, Gary Oldman, and Brion James (who also appears in it's inspiration, Blade Runner - a MUCH better film) are wasted here. I guess it's meant to be a comedy, but its dialog is just embarrassingly bad, and the actor's can't save it. There are much better comedies, and much better sci-fi films out there. If you know you already like this stuff, this review is irrelevant. For those who haven't yet seen this film, you may find it literally unwatchable. Please rent it first. Don't waste your money buying this, unless you want it as a demo disc, or just like dumb comedies. I was so misled by the high number of 5 star reviews. Oh well.

reviewText: This remastered Blu-Ray version was watched on a Panasonic 42" Plasma and BD35K player. PQ 4/5 and AQ 5/5.I had not seen this film in a few years and found the visuals, and overarching storyline refreshing. The costume design and visual look of the film was particularly interesting and offered stylistic elements not seen on film since. The creatures seemed reminiscent of the Dark Crystal, which is one of my favorite films, so it felt familiar in that sense.The characters were relatable, and the "perfect" being was particularly touching as a "messenger" of sorts, in communicating our inherent habit of destroying ourselves, which of course, is one of the central themes of the film. Though not preachy, this characters' innocense and emphasis on this theme recentered the film to the core concepts effectively. Despite the fact that the film is filled with visually interesting effects and sound design/effects, this allows the film to remain humanistic. Many science fiction films fail in this regard, instead becoming overshadowed with technological aspects and special effects, but the Fifth Element stays true to its underlying message of the need and appreciation for love and the importance of humanity.Overall, this film was entertaining and action packed. However, I didn't give it a 5, because it seemed to lag in parts and some of the acting was overdone, in a way, that was too distracting, for me. Still for its visual elemements and overall theme, it was one of the most interesting sci-fi flicks I've seen. Recommended.
summary: Interesting costume design, existential story line

reviewText: Visually, THE FIFTH ELEMENT is a stunner.  Anyone who ever doubted that a French writer/director couldn't handle a big budget Bruce Willis extravaganza will have to manger his chapeau.  And for those of us who like our Sci-Fi mixed with a little mysticism, Luc Besson's film does it better than say THE BLACK HOLE or EVENT HORIZON.  And who could deny that Milla Jovovich isn't perfectly cast as the embodiment of the divine? The film is quite entertaining, and a cut above the usual Willis fare.  His bleach job alone should tell you that they were going after something a little different here. Still fans of the wise-cracking adventure hero should still love it, and those who just like an oddball futuristic yarn with great visuals and a sense of humor should go for this as well.  Not deep space nor deep thinking but still good intelligent fun.

reviewText: The Fifth Element has got to be the worst movie I have ever seen, and I am dumbfounded by the good reviews it seems to have received here on Amazon.Bruce Willis's character is not very bright and makes poor decisions. The female alien, with orange hair, is supposed to be a DNA-induced clone of a race that was bright enough to navigate to earth, yet the character is child-like, immature, and knows nothing and does not seem to be able to learn. So tell me, how does this ignorant alien be part of a race advanced enough for space travel?Mainly the film is supposed to be a comedy, but it jumps back and forth between such unrelated scenes that it is a confusing mess. The things that are supposed to be funny are simply annoying.How it suddenly goes into an opera concert, I cannot even begin to explain that one. Again, an unrelated, meaningless scene that is truly painful to watch and even worse to listen to.Stay clear of this drivel. It is a mess of a film that does not work on any level. Comedy? Really? If you decide to ignore my review and go with the ones who give it five stars, do so at your own risk. You have been warned.

reviewText: Amazon tends to blend reviews together- so first let me note I'm talking about the standard DVD Ultimate Edition of the movie.This is one of the most instantly quotable, most visually memorable, frenetic space operas ever committed to film. I recently re-watched the film with my fiancee. The first thing I noticed was that the film is still as fresh as it was at release- absolutely nothing about the film shows its age (though it's not exactly old anyway). The second was just how consistently good this film is. Both of us were constantly saying, "This next scene is my favorite scene" only to correct that when the next great scene came up, and so on, and so on. The ultimate realization is that virtually every single scene in the film is funny, relevant, and drives the plot forward- and that's what a great film is made of. Seeing "Tiny" Lister in his turn as the President of Earth should be enough of a clue as to just how off-beat and funny this film is.What do you get in the Ultimate Edition? Not much really. The star of the package is still the film itself. Nothing has been re-edited or re-mastered or re-anything in the film, but then again, nothing at all needed upgraded anyway. There are lots of featurettes, including dissections of all the characters with interviews and even some screen tests (men may want to note the drool-worthy screen tests of Milla Jovovich). A good selection of documentaries are also included, and most notable is the feature talking about the visual design. The sets and futuristic aspects of the film are as much of a character as Korben Dallas (Bruce Willis) and crew. "The Visual Element" goes all the way back to the roots of French artist moebius to tell exactly how the designs came about- film students need to give this documentary segment repeated viewings.Now go out and get this movie! Go! Bzzzz! Bzzz-zzz! (...you need to see this movie)

reviewText: This review is in regards to the Superbit version of the 5th Element DVD.I think the movie is mildly entertaining.  It doesn't have great replay value, but overall it was not-so-serious enough to take the movie in for what it is: an over the top sci-fi action/adventure.  If your looking for more on the merit of the movie, peruse the 600+ subsequent reviews.I bought the Superbit movie for $10; this retailer apparently is attempting to unload Superbit product since apparently it is not in demand.  And this is troubling to me.This copy of the movie is visually stunning.  With a good DVD player, the picture rivals HD picture quality.  It is one of the better looking DVDs in my collection (one that features other Superbit movies).  Also, the Superbit version features a very balanced DTS audio track that makes ample use of your surround and subwoofer speakers.Soapbox time.  I scratch my head trying to figure out why Audio/Video consumers will drop $3000 on an HD TV and settle for poor quality DVD transfers because they want the special features they'll never watch more than once.  Thanks to this disturbing trend, Sony (and other movie studios) have been reluctant to release movies in formats similar to Superbit.  I guess salvation will come with the eventual winner of the HD DVD war; too bad this salvation will come with a stiff price.The movie gets 3 stars.The DVD transfer gets 5 stars.

reviewText: Taking place in 23rd century New York, where flying cars pollute the skies, this futuristic thriller, directed by Luc Besson, is one of the most colorful, vibrant, visually ostentatious films ever made. In it, a taxi-driver with Special Forces training (Bruce Willis) is caught off guard when a scantily-clad, orange-haired clone named Leeloo (Milla Jovovich) falls into his backseat. Regarded and referred to as "the perfect being," Leeloo represents the good in an intergalactic war against Evil, and is humankind's last hope for survival--she is the Fifth Element. Gary Oldman, Ian Holm and Chris Tucker round up a collective cast that fits impeccably with the pace and story Besson offers viewers, and are each indispensable in their respective roles. As a whole, however, The Fifth Element seems burdened by its own objective, which is to overwhelm its audience's senses. Had it slowed down a bit to focus more on the characters at its center, the film would have been much more successful as a motion picture; instead, it's just a pretty good article of entertainment. The remastered Blu-ray edition enhances Besson's beautiful imagery enough that fans of the film will have reason to make the HD upgrade, but only fans.

reviewText: Oh, my word! I have tried to watch this film numerous times and have lost interest within the first 20 minutes. I love films of all sorts, but this one just sucks. It seems that the director wanted to make everything completely over the top and he achieved his goal in spades, believe me. I skipped around to see if it got better and of course, it didn't. UGH!!! What a waste of talent! If you want to see something a lot better, try the entire Star Wars collection, Titan AE (animated, but still 100x better than this)or even Event Horizon. This will be a future film for the Mystery Science Theater guys to make fun of. Then, at least, it will be funny. At this point, it is just sad.

reviewText: What can I say? Bruce Willis is at his best, and Milla, an actress, a model, and a singer, all in one, (no, not in the movie), brings her character to life in a beautiful way, like the unfurling of a rose.The clincher for me was the character, Plavalaguna, the Diva, whose singing performance left me STUNNED. Granted, although I knew it was a bit tweaked, her vocal performance on stage, as well as her presence is enough alone to see this movie, if just to watch her perform "The Mad Scene" from the opera, "Lucia Di Lamamoor". A REAL twist on it, that one must see to experience.

reviewText: If you are looking for the ultimate cheesy Blu-Ray movie experience, this is it.Luc Besson's sumptuous sci-fi visuals are impressive in high-definition.  The film's multiple opening stories would become tedious and irrelevant if not for the beautifully rendered surroundings.  Why worry about continuity, internal consistency, or even common sense when you have vehicles flying through cityscapes in 1080p?  Some of the widescreen shots of space, or the Egyptian landscape, are as startlingly wide and breathtaking as the holes in the plot.And let's not forget the audio.  Badly choreographed fight scenes gain extra oomph from the surround sound and deep subwoofer impacts.  You'll forget about the poor tactics and marksmanship as the sound of bullets (which of course miss all the main protagonists) zip past your ears in stereo.  When accompanied by the awkward and ill-advised opera-turned-pop-song vocals, the state-of-the-art audio-visual experience approaches something like a rollercoaster ride on a full stomach.As with all great movies, this works at multiple levels.  When Lelu discovers War (finally getting to the "W" section of the encyclopedia), she flips through repetitive pictures of old battlefields.  She is forced to sit through several minutes of this, and finally breaks down and cries.  The adolescent imagery and emotions are a microcosm for the audience's own experience with the film.The climax of the film really brings everything together: doubts about humanity, dubiously phallic superweapons with poor instruction manuals, inappropriately timed professions of love, and shatteringly poor dialog.  It doesn't get any better than this.My only complaint: there wasn't much else on the Blu-Ray.  A couple more previews would have been cool.
summary: See this spectacularly bad movie in spectacular high-definition!

reviewText: I have this movie on VHS, DVD, and now on my laptop. I love this movie It is very entertaining. Its adventure, comical, its a love story, has villains, heroes, and just plain good. I watch it over and over and each time I see something I've missed previously. Bruce Willis does what he does best. Gary Oldman is one of my favorites , and Ian Holm-------so I enjoy every minute of it. When your day has gone all wrong or you want to relax and you just want to curl up and think of nothing, its a good movie to curl up with.
summary: Five stars wish I could give it a lot more--

reviewText: I rented this movie for $3.99 (kind of a rip off but I was too lazy to find a physical rental copy) with my Amazon Prime membership. Rental only lasts 24 hours which makes Redbox about a buck 50 cheaper. Anyway... We have high-speed Internet so the download/streaming quality was fine. The movie was as good as I remembered it. I hadn't seen it in about 10 years.So 5 stars for the movie, and 3 stars for the Amazon rental for a short rental period plus a relatively high price. I used to work in the video rental business and $3.99 would have been the price of a new release for 5 days so this is what I am used to. An older movie would have been $1.99, maybe $2.49 because it was Blu-ray but still old. I feel like Redbox is a bit of a ripoff even because you only get 24 hours. :p

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Bresson's film has moments of visual beauty and an interesting set up, but the narrative falls apart midway through the film. Still, one can't help but enjoy the satire sprinkled throughout the film.Willis gives  a...typical Willis performance. The real standout here is Ian Holm. Holm  adds a tounge-in-cheek quality to his befuddled priest. Gary Oldman's over  the top Bugs Bunny on speed performance adds to the fun of the film as  well.Clearly Bresson was attempting a broad satire and is, for the most  part, sucessful. He uses Hitchcock's McGuffin to set up the plot. Bresson's  McGuffin doesn't completely work--he seems to lose track of the narrative  midway through the film and concentrates, instead, on a series of fun set  pieces. This doesn't make for a very cohensive narrative. Although the  McGuffin was merely the catalyst in Hitch's films to move the story forward  they, nonetheless, were always resolved. Here, Bresson can't seem to quite  figure out how to end his film.As a result, the film becomes another  run of the mill sf candy store of visuals, odd aliens and over the top  performances.The DVD transfer is terrific. The picture sparkles and the  sound has tremendous punch(unlike early DVD's where the surround sound was  usually poorly mixed). On technical points the film deserves a 4 or 5 star  rating, for the film itself, though, 3 star will do.
summary: Less than the sum of its parts
